results.title: The Melbourne Games
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Video Sports and Golden Years
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
Live through the unforgettable action for the first time the Olympic Flame blazed in the Southern Hemisphere. This program captures the momentous highs and lows Australians were able to savour first hand. It includes footage of the remarkable first, second and third places captured by Australian swimmers in the women’s 100m final, headed by the fabulous Dawn Fraser. The explosive confrontation between Hungarian and Russian water polo teams, less than three weeks after the Russian invasion. The pride of Betty Cuthbert’s glorious wins in the 100m, 200m and 4 x 100m relay races. Plus all the local magic of a youthful nation hosting the world’s premiere sporting competition. Narrated by Norman May.

results.title: The Melbourne Concert Hall
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan, The Victorian Arts Centre and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Interviews with architects, administrators, interior designers, construction workers and others associated with the construction of the Melbourne Concert Hall. Artists who have performed at the venue also give their opinion of hall. Those interviewed include: Roy Ground, Neil Haysom, Theodore Schultz, Ken Myer, John Truscott and Kenny Christophers. Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.

results.title: The Meiji adventure
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Presenter, Keith Adam, describes Japan’s leap from feudal outpost to modern nation by recounting the history of the Meiji dynasty that led to this amazing social transformation.

results.title: The Mehinacu
results.creator_credit: Carlos Pasini and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The men and women of the Mehinacu, in central Brazil, live harmoniously in the five family houses of their small village, but conflict and separation of the sexes is an everyday fact of life - with the men and women performing distinctly different roles and tasks in order to thrive together. This film is a record of the elaborate rituals that take a month to complete, and are central to the Mehinacu way of life - a unique and colourful system of custom and taboo that may not survive the modern world.

results.title: The Meeting place
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Catherine Duncan
results.brief_description: The town of Nuriootpa - an aboriginal word meaning “the meeting place” - lies in the rich Barossa valley in South Australia, about fifty miles from Adelaide. Although superficially Nuriootpa may appear to be much like any other Australian country town, it is in fact a place where co-operation and collective effort have won for the community many facilities which most country towns lack. Acting through a community committee consisting of representee of the residents of Nuriootpa, a hotel and a co-operative store have been established a technical school and youth centre opened, a swimming pool and a health centre built, and plans for future development drawn up.

results.title: The Meeting
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker, John Howe and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A discussion film designed to raise questions about how much support an elected group should be entitled to expect from its electorate. At a meeting of a community group, a committee, delegated to choose a play to be staged, makes its choice known. A split occurs when some disagree and it seems that the committee may be overruled.

results.title: The Medium is the massage, you know
results.creator_credit: Trevor Greenwood, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The medium, of course, is television, and those massaged are the vast viewing audience. But this 1969 film is not an enquiry into the effects of television on the viewer, although there are some expressions of opinion in man-on-the-street interviews. For the most part, the film takes place in a Vancouver classroom where young students are given the facilities (camera, TV monitor, videotape recorder) to stage their own little act for the television screen. What they do reveals the impact that television has had on them.

results.title: The Mediterranean
results.creator_credit: Tom Naughton, Christopher Bryson, Joe Wiecha, Marianna Edmunds, Bertand Morin, Nicolas Valcour, Learning Channel, Quai 32 and New Dominion Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Archaeology”.
John Rhys-Davis narrates five excellent episodes which showcases archaeological exploration around the Mediterranean. French divers discover a cave filled with 18,000 year old rock paintings in “A Cave beneath the sea.” The Minoan colony of the island of Thera is shown in “Lost city of the Aegean.” The daily life of ancient Egypt is unlocked in “Forgotten mummies.” After World War 2, Schliemann’s discoveries at Troy, disappeared and the mystery is investigated in “Lost treasures of Troy.” The secret rituals of the women of Lesbos in Ancient Greece is the subject of the final episode entitled “Women of Lesbos.”

results.title: The Medieval mind
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: An introduction to the unique character of the ‘medieval mind’. The film explains how medieval thought was fraught with tension and conflict and contrasts its world view with that of more recent times. Some of the conflicts within the Church are discussed and come medieval art, architecture and iconography is surveyed.
